title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: From Moniaive they followed thewindings of a flashing burn, daching and roaring in a shallowlinn, here and there white with foam and fretting, and againdimpling black in some deep and quiet pool.

title: Ruth Farmer. A story
author: Marchbank, Agnes.
snippet: Mrs. Johnstone, meanwhile, seized the opportunity of stopping the ticking of the clock, for it isheld in Moniaive that the sound of a clock tickingbeside the dying, disturbs the spirit.

snippet: He was ayoung man, but newly come to the Free Kirk ofMoniaive, and this was his first experience of a deathbed.

snippet: For, as there was no need to waste oilin showing outsiders what vvas in Davie Johnstone'swindows—everybody in Moniaive knew their contents

title: Ruth Farmer. A story

snippet: Everybody in andabout Moniaive knew that Davie Johnstone soldbread, fancy and plain, also self-rising flour, fine oatmeal, best fresh butter and eggs.

title: Ruth Farmer. A story
author: Marchbank, Agnes.
snippet: To hear, however, thatshe was probably alive was indeed exciting; andhe there and then began to wonder how this newswould affect the village of Moniaive.

title: Ruth Farmer. A story
author: Marchbank, Agnes.
snippet: In all ofthe cottage gardens spring flowers were making thingsbright—cowslip and primrose and narcissus, scillasand hyacinths and anemones, daisies and pansies andauriculas, were lending all sorts of colour to thecottage gardens in Moniaive.

title: Ruth Farmer. A story

snippet: " Please, sir, I was at Moniaive, sir," said he, as heexamined the brim of his felt hat.

title: Ruth Farmer. A story

snippet: Like all the womankind in Moniaive, Miss Betsy liked a good gossip,and wanted to see if any people or parcels weregoing from Havannah.

title: Ruth Farmer. A story
author: Marchbank, Agnes.
snippet: The doings at Havannah were now the talk of thegood people of Moniaive, and Davie Johnstone walkedup daily to inspect the improvements, even wanderingat his own sweet will into the house, of which he soongot to know every corner.
